questions.question_text:
Your company (your-company.com) just acquired a new business (new-company.com) that is running their email on-premises. It is close to their peak season, so any major changes need to be postponed. However, you need to ensure that the users at the new business can receive email addressed to them using your- company.com into their on-premises email server. You need to set up an email routing policy to accomplish this.
What steps should you take?

discussion.content: sorry typo. It is D

Vote for D

https://support.google.com/a/answer/2685650?hl=en

D is correct!
https://support.google.com/a/answer/2685650?hl=en
"...If you're migrating to Gmail from a legacy server, use split delivery to test Gmail with a subset of users. During the testing, the MX records for your domain point to Gmail. Users who have been added in the Admin console get messages in their Gmail inboxes. Set up a catch-all routing rule for unregistered users who need to get messages from the legacy mail server."

Selected Answer: D
https://support.google.com/a/answer/2685650?hl=en
C is the correct answer 100% , I asked a Gsuite Admin

comments.content: Do not agree, if all inbound mail was rerouted then it would deliver mail for the on-prem server and not to Workspace for the current users.

discussion.content: D is correct

C correct answer
"It is close to their peak season, so any major changes need to be postponed."
So we will no any change in legacy System 
https://support.google.com/a/answer/2685650#zippy=%2Croute-messages-with-dual-delivery

Voto por la D porque la C dice que es enviar TODO el correo entrante al servidor y no es lo que quieren, ellos quieren dividir que el correo vaya a google y a otro servidor, por eso es mejor configurar una entrega dividida, respuesta D
Its D - It only talks about split delivery not dual delivery (which would create two emails)
It´s C because you don´t have to leave any emails of this domain on gsuite so it´s no use of split or dual delivery

The correct anwser is D.
Split Delivery/Dual delivery means what it implies: delivering mail to both Gmail and on-premises server.And it doesn't make sense to deliver to both destinations.

Similar problem.
https://blog.resellerclub.com/g-suite-split-delivery-and-how-to-configure-split-dns/
C - because you can have more domain with users, but we shuld route only inbound mail from one domain
But why D rather than C?
Vote for B

choices.A: Set up an Outbound Mail Gateway to route all outbound email to the on-premises server.
choices.B: Set up accounts for the new employees, and use mail forwarding rules to send to the on-premises server.
choices.C: Set up an Inbound Mail Gateway to reroute all inbound email to the on-premises server.
choices.D: Set up a Default route with split delivery to route email to the on-premises server.

discussion.content: B is correct
B is correct option here

questions.question_text:
A user does not follow their usual sign-in pattern and signs in from an unusual location.
What type of alert is triggered by this event?

choices.C: The Google Form will need to be limited to internal users only.
choices.D: The Apps Script will need to run on a timed interval to process new entries.
choices.B: You will need a Cloud SQL instance to store "G-Team' data.
choices.A: The Apps Script will need to run as a G Suite admin.
choices.E: The Google Form will need to enforce Group naming conventions.

discussion.content:
prefer A and C. you need Admin SDK API to create group, which requires admin role
For D - we can choose to use trigger (upon new entry) also

comments.content: c, term "securely" has to be implemented by internal use.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Apps Script must be runned as a G Suite admin + Google Form will need to be limited to internal users only for security purpose

Selected Answer: AC
To do this, the Apps Script must be runned as a G Suite admin + Google Form will need to be limited to internal users only for security purpose
A+C is correct
Would A and C be the best option?
I also vote for A and C.

questions.question_text:
Your large organization, 80,000 users, has been on Google for two years. Your CTO wants to create an integrated team experience with Google Groups, Teams
Drives, and Calendar. Users will use a Google Form and Apps Script to request a new "G-Team." A "G-Team' is composed of a Google Group and a Team Drive/
Secondary Calendar that is shared using that Google Group.
What two design decisions are required to implement this workflow securely? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Whitelist the app in the G Suite Marketplace.
choices.A: Enable all API access for Google Drive.
choices.C: Add OAuth Client ID to Google Drive Trusted List.

discussion.content: (B) https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en

Selected Answer: C
I think it's C.
Because the Information Security Policy establishes permission based on approved whitelists.

Selected Answer: C
Trusting all domain-owned apps is not secured in this case.
C allows to choose what app is whitelisted and not all apps developped internally and not approved.

I vote C. 
You are already restricting access (using whitelist) so the internal app will get blocked. see: "Let internal apps access restricted Google Workspace APIs". So you need to get around it by adding the Auth information as indicated in "Manage access to apps: Trusted, Limited, or Blocked." 

https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en
C is correct
Would option C be the correct answer?

comments.content:
(B) is correct. (Agree with @nwk. )
You can go to Security > API controls. Under App access control, check the Trust internal, Domain-owned apps box

discussion.content:
C is correct answer here. 

https://support.google.com/a/answer/162106?hl=en

https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en

Section - Add or remove an app from the trusted list
Trust specific apps that you want accessing all G Suite services (OAuth scopes)
Not able to restrict to just Google Drive for the Trusted List

questions.question_text:
The application development team has come to you requesting that a new, internal, domain-owned G Suite app be allowed to access Google Drive APIs. You are currently restricting access to all APIs using approved whitelists, per security policy. You need to grant access for this app.
What should you do?

discussion.content: (C) https://support.google.com/a/answer/167430?hl=en
(C) -https://support.google.com/a/answer/167430?hl=en#:~:text=Google%20Groups%20Collaborative%20Inboxes%20are,support%20or%20customer%20service%20teams.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. D doesn't make sense
C is correct. https://support.google.com/a/answer/167430?hl=en

Selected Answer: C
C is the best practice.
A will only spread the incoming mails to all members without any information of assignments or replies, B doesnt allow different access levels and D is wrong.
C is correct
Answer C, would it be correct?
C. https://support.google.com/a/answer/167430?hl=en
C is correct answer and best option here.

comments.content: I think it is (C). It say various levels of access. With (B) delegates only have one level of access, which is Full access.

discussion.content:
Should Be (B), question states User Account, and managed by multiple employees
https://support.google.com/a/users/answer/170957?hl=en

choices.D: Configure a Google Group, and set the Access Level to Announcement Only.
choices.B: Delegate email access to department employees.
choices.A: Configure a Google Group as an email list.
choices.C: Configure a Google Group as a collaborative inbox.

questions.question_text:
Your organization's Sales Department uses a generic user account (sales@company.com) to manage requests. With only one employee responsible for managing the departmental account, you are tasked with providing the department with the most efficient means to allow multiple employees various levels of access and manage requests from a common email address.
What should you do?
